title: DOGE Analysis: 48,785 Transactions, 1,311 Duplicate Groups, and the Lowest Spend With the Highest Volume
summary: Our comprehensive DOGE-style audit of Pendle's £127 million in spending reveals the highest transaction volume of any East Lancashire council, with 1,311 duplicate payment groups and £19.5 million in suspected split payments.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Companies House Compliance: Pendle's Cleanest Record Still Raises Questions
summary: Pendle paid £37,800 to four suppliers during active Companies House breaches — the lowest exposure of the three East Lancashire councils. But two suppliers filed dormant accounts while actively receiving council payments.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: 1,311 Duplicate Payment Groups: The Most of Any East Lancashire Council
summary: Despite having the lowest total spend, Pendle has the most duplicate payment groups — 1,311 totalling £2.7 million. The high volume of small transactions (48,785 in total) appears to drive the elevated duplication rate.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: 5,047 Fuel Transactions, £6M to Other Councils, and £20M in Round Numbers
summary: Pendle's spending data reveals unusual patterns: Fuelmate Ltd generated 5,047 transactions, Brentwood and Surrey councils each received £3 million in unexplained transfers, and £20.1 million was paid in suspiciously round numbers.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Cross-Council Comparison: 44 Shared Suppliers and a 115,237% Price Gap
summary: Pendle shares 44 suppliers with Burnley and Hyndburn totalling £40.2 million. Both Burnley and Pendle pay Liberata UK millions for outsourced services — but Burnley pays more than double. One truck supplier shows a 115,237% price variation.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Liberata's £54 Million: Pendle's Biggest Supplier Under Scrutiny
summary: Liberata UK Ltd has received £54 million from Pendle — the largest Liberata contract across all three East Lancashire councils. With Burnley bringing services back in-house, questions mount about why Pendle pays 40% more per resident than its neighbour.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Homelessness Costs Up 5,400%: Pendle's Fastest-Growing Budget Crisis
summary: Pendle's homelessness expenditure has surged by over 5,400% — one of the fastest increases of any district council in England. Temporary accommodation costs and enhanced housing benefit claims are driving a budget crisis that threatens other services.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: PEARL: Public Money, Private Control?
summary: PEARL (Pendle Enterprise and Regeneration Ltd) combines public assets with private investment for regeneration. With council joint ventures failing nationally — from Croydon's Brick by Brick to Nottingham's Robin Hood Energy — governance questions demand answers.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Pendle's Financial Time Bomb: Reserves Exhaustion by 2027
summary: Grant Thornton has identified 'significant weaknesses' in Pendle's financial sustainability. With a cumulative budget gap of £8.26M by 2025/26 and reserves being drawn down to balance the books, usable reserves could be exhausted by 2027/28 — putting the council in Section 114 notice territory.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Pendle's Leisure Centre Subsidy: £1.9M Per Year Extended to 2033
summary: During a period of auditor-flagged financial crisis, Pendle extended its leisure management contract to 2033 — committing taxpayers to an estimated £15-19M in subsidies. At nearly £21 per resident, Pendle's leisure subsidy is almost double Burnley's.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Pendle's Planning Service: The Most Expensive in the North West
summary: The LGA flagged Pendle's planning service costs as the highest of any district council in the North West. At an estimated £3,000+ per application — 50-80% above the regional average — the planning department is a significant net drain on Pendle's stretched general fund.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Pendle's Audit Disclaimer: What It Means When Auditors Can't Sign Off
summary: Pendle's 2023/24 accounts received a disclaimer of opinion — the most serious audit outcome possible. Combined with Grant Thornton's 'significant weaknesses' finding, two of three East Lancashire councils now have disclaimers, raising fundamental questions about financial governance.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Waste: The £2.6M Bill Coming in 2026
summary: The closure of Whinney Hill landfill and the government's food waste collection mandate will add approximately £2.6M to Pendle's costs — roughly 20% of the entire net revenue budget. For a council already facing reserves exhaustion, this may be the straw that breaks the camel's back.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Lancashire's Liberata Problem: £90M+ to One Company Across Two Councils
summary: Liberata UK Ltd has received over £90M combined from Burnley and Pendle councils for outsourced services. Burnley is ending its contract and bringing services in-house from 2026, yet Pendle's £54M contract continues — at £591 per resident, more than four times what Hyndburn spends delivering equivalent services in-house.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: The LGR Endgame: What Happens to Debts, Contracts, and Reserves When Councils Merge
summary: Lancashire's Local Government Reorganisation will merge 12 district councils into new unitary authorities. But who inherits Burnley's £80M+ commercial property debt, Pendle's £54M Liberata contract, and Hyndburn's depleted reserves? Lessons from Northamptonshire, Cumbria, and Somerset suggest transition costs are always higher than promised.
author: Pendle Council Transparency

title: Waste Disposal: Lancashire's Shared Crisis
summary: All three East Lancashire councils face a simultaneous waste crisis: Whinney Hill landfill has closed, the food waste collection mandate requires new infrastructure, and LCC is restructuring disposal arrangements. Combined additional costs could exceed £8-10M per year across the three boroughs — with Hyndburn reportedly lacking a waste transfer station entirely.
author: Pendle Council Transparency
